qas.question: What are called factions by some people?
What are political parties lobbied by?

answers.text: organizations, businesses and special interest groups

qas.question: What are traditional sources of funding for parties?
Around which time was the mass membership party started?
What do some people still call trade unions?
What do special interest groups receive for paying membership dues?

plausible_answers.text: organizations, businesses and special interest groups

qas.question: What groups support having to pay trade unions?
During what time were lobbyists the most prevalent in government?
What newly founded party opposed all government?

context: <a0_0>Political parties<a0_0/>, still called <b4_0>factions<b4_0/> by some, especially those in the governmental apparatus, are lobbied vigorously by <a1_0><b6_0>organizations, businesses and special interest groups<b6_0/><a1_0/> such as trade unions. <a2_0><b5_0>Money and gifts<b5_0/><a2_0/>-in-kind to a party, or its leading members, may be offered as incentives. Such donations are the traditional source of funding for all right-of-centre cadre parties. Starting in the late <a3_0><b7_0>19th century<b7_0/><a3_0/> these parties were opposed by the newly founded <b8_0>left-of-centre workers' parties<b8_0/>. They started a new party type, the mass membership party, and a new source of political fundraising, membership dues.
